headline: Paramount Skydance wins Warner Bros; Netflix walks away and its shares jump
summary: Feb 26 (Reuters) - Paramount Skydance emerged as the likely winner in a months-long battle to acquire Warner Bros Discovery, after streaming giant Netflix on Thursday refused to raise its bid for the storied Hollywood studio. "We've always been disciplined, and at the price required to ‌match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid," Netflix said in a ‌statement.

content.title: Paramount Skydance wins Warner Bros; Netflix walks away and its shares jump
content.summary: Feb 26 (Reuters) - Paramount Skydance emerged as the likely winner in a months-long battle to acquire Warner Bros Discovery, after streaming giant Netflix on Thursday refused to raise its bid for the storied Hollywood studio. "We've always been disciplined, and at the price required to ‌match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid," Netflix said in a ‌statement.

headline: Netflix backs out of bid for Warner Bros after Paramount's new offer
summary:
STORY: Netflix said on Thursday that it was backing out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It comes shortly after Warner Bros said a revised $31-per-share offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

In a statement, Netflix said (quote) "at the price required to match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid." 

Netflix, which wanted to buy the Warner Bros streaming and studio businesses, agreed in December to pay $27.75 a share, saying the offer, along with a planned spinoff of Warner Bros' cable assets, would deliver a greater shareholder value.

Paramount, meanwhile, has argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

On Thursday, Paramount said it welcomed Warner Bros board's unanimous reaffirmation that its bid represents the stronger offer.

content.title: Netflix backs out of bid for Warner Bros after Paramount's new offer
content.summary:
STORY: Netflix said on Thursday that it was backing out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It comes shortly after Warner Bros said a revised $31-per-share offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

In a statement, Netflix said (quote) "at the price required to match Paramount Skydance's latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid." 

Netflix, which wanted to buy the Warner Bros streaming and studio businesses, agreed in December to pay $27.75 a share, saying the offer, along with a planned spinoff of Warner Bros' cable assets, would deliver a greater shareholder value.

Paramount, meanwhile, has argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

On Thursday, Paramount said it welcomed Warner Bros board's unanimous reaffirmation that its bid represents the stronger offer.

headline: Netflix Drops Warner Bros. Bid, Leaving Paramount the Winner
summary: “We’ve always been disciplined, and at the price required to match Paramount Skydance’s latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive,” Netflix said Thursday in a statement.  Netflix shares jumped more than 13% in after-hours trading, indicating that investors were happy to see the company walk away from the deal.  Warner Bros. fell, with investors no longer anticipating a bidding war.

Warner Bros. fell, with investors no longer anticipating a bidding war.

headline: Netflix withdraws Warner Bros bid as Paramount offer declared 'superior'
summary: Paramount Skydance is on course to win the Warner Bros Discovery (WBD) takeover battle after rival Netflix stepped away.  The World's largest streaming service had been in pole position to land a deal by which it would pay $27.75 per share for Warner's studio and HBO Max streaming businesses, valuing the divisions at almost $83bn (£61.6bn) including debt.  Netflix had been invited to raise its bid after Paramount submitted a final offer, for the whole WBD business, of $31 per share earlier this week that ultimately concluded a ping-pong process of sweetened bids.

content.title: Netflix withdraws Warner Bros bid as Paramount offer declared 'superior'
content.summary: Paramount Skydance is on course to win the Warner Bros Discovery (WBD) takeover battle after rival Netflix stepped away.  The World's largest streaming service had been in pole position to land a deal by which it would pay $27.75 per share for Warner's studio and HBO Max streaming businesses, valuing the divisions at almost $83bn (£61.6bn) including debt.  Netflix had been invited to raise its bid after Paramount submitted a final offer, for the whole WBD business, of $31 per share earlier this week that ultimately concluded a ping-pong process of sweetened bids.

headline: Netflix, Paramount shares jump as months-long fight for Warner Bros ends
summary: Netflix jumped more than 9% premarket on Friday as investors cheered its decision to exit the fight for Warner Bros ‌Discovery, while Paramount rose about 10% on winning the race for ‌some of the world's most prized TV and film assets.  Warner Bros shares were marginally lower.  Paramount Skydance maintained its dogged pursuit of Warner Bros, launching ‌a hostile campaign to wrest ⁠the prize from Netflix.

headline: Paramount Stock Is Rallying. Now It Can Go Head-to-Head With Netflix.
summary: Paramount Skydance  investors look like they could get a fairytale ending, with the CBS owner set to win the  Warner Bros. Discovery  bidding war.  It’s a great outcome for Paramount, which only had to raise its hostile tender offer by $1 a share to avoid a prolonged bidding war.  Paramount’s latest proposal also includes a 25 cents a share ticking fee, payable to Warner shareholders for each quarter the deal hasn’t closed after Sept. 30.

headline: Netflix Drops Discovery Bid, Clearing Way for Paramount
summary: Netflix Inc. dropped out of the fight to buy Warner Bros. Discovery Inc., saying that while it believed its deal would have passed muster with regulators and created shareholder value, it didn't want to keep bidding. The move clears the way for rival bidder Paramount Skydance Corp. to clinch its $111 billion deal for the historic Hollywood studio. Bloomberg's Manuel Baigorri breaks down the situation.

content.title: Netflix Drops Discovery Bid, Clearing Way for Paramount
content.description: Netflix Inc. dropped out of the fight to buy Warner Bros. Discovery Inc., saying that while it believed its deal would have passed muster with regulators and created shareholder value, it didn't want to keep bidding. The move clears the way for rival bidder Paramount Skydance Corp. to clinch its $111 billion deal for the historic Hollywood studio. Bloomberg's Manuel Baigorri breaks down the situation.
content.summary: Netflix Inc. dropped out of the fight to buy Warner Bros. Discovery Inc., saying that while it believed its deal would have passed muster with regulators and created shareholder value, it didn't want to keep bidding. The move clears the way for rival bidder Paramount Skydance Corp. to clinch its $111 billion deal for the historic Hollywood studio. Bloomberg's Manuel Baigorri breaks down the situation.

headline: The Week in Numbers: 94% sales hike, multibillion-dollar deals
summary:
STORY: From a mega sales hike for Nvidia to multibillion-dollar deals, 

This is the Week in Numbers.

:: The Week in Numbers

:: 94% 

94% is the amount by which Nvidia’s January-quarter sales jumped. 

The chip giant posted forecast-beating revenue for the period of $68.13 billion.

It expects current quarter sales of $78 billion.

Nvidia executives told investors it had secured enough chip inventory and capacity to meet demand beyond the next several quarters.

:: $31

$31 per share was Paramount’s offer to buy Warner Bros Discovery. 

Which saw Netflix back out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It said the offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

Paramount had argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

:: $19 billion

A $19 billion share sale is Toyota's aim for as early as this year.  

Two sources spoke to Reuters about this strategic move…

As the automaker looks to banks and financial institutions to sell up.

It could mark a shift in Toyota’s governance reform, which remains under investor scrutiny. 

The sources said the sale figure could be larger than $19 billion depending on the willingness of shareholders to sell.

:: 50%

50% is the maximum amount Novo Nordisk will slash the U.S. prices of Ozempic and Wegovy by. 

The Danish pharma said on Tuesday that the price cuts for the blockbuster diabetes and weight-loss drugs will be effective from January next year.

And will coincide with the implementation of new, lower prices for the same drugs under federal Medicare health plans for older adults.

The market for so-called GLP-1 drugs has been getting increasingly competitive.

And both Ozempic and Wegovy will list for $675 a month.

:: $60 billion

$60 billion worth of AMD’s AI chips will be sold to Meta over the next five years. 

It’s a deal that’ll allow the Facebook owner to purchase as much as 10% of the chip firm. 

It’s AMD’s second mega chip supply deal, having signed a similar pact with OpenAI last year. 

The move was considered a vote of confidence in AMD’s chips and software, significantly boosting its stock price.

content.title: The Week in Numbers: 94% sales hike, multibillion-dollar deals
content.summary:
STORY: From a mega sales hike for Nvidia to multibillion-dollar deals, 

This is the Week in Numbers.

:: The Week in Numbers

:: 94% 

94% is the amount by which Nvidia’s January-quarter sales jumped. 

The chip giant posted forecast-beating revenue for the period of $68.13 billion.

It expects current quarter sales of $78 billion.

Nvidia executives told investors it had secured enough chip inventory and capacity to meet demand beyond the next several quarters.

:: $31

$31 per share was Paramount’s offer to buy Warner Bros Discovery. 

Which saw Netflix back out of its bid to buy Warner Bros Discovery's streaming and studio assets.

It said the offer from Paramount Skydance was superior to its existing deal with Netflix.

Paramount had argued it has a clearer path to U.S. regulatory approval.

:: $19 billion

A $19 billion share sale is Toyota's aim for as early as this year.  

Two sources spoke to Reuters about this strategic move…

As the automaker looks to banks and financial institutions to sell up.

It could mark a shift in Toyota’s governance reform, which remains under investor scrutiny. 

The sources said the sale figure could be larger than $19 billion depending on the willingness of shareholders to sell.

:: 50%

50% is the maximum amount Novo Nordisk will slash the U.S. prices of Ozempic and Wegovy by. 

The Danish pharma said on Tuesday that the price cuts for the blockbuster diabetes and weight-loss drugs will be effective from January next year.

And will coincide with the implementation of new, lower prices for the same drugs under federal Medicare health plans for older adults.

The market for so-called GLP-1 drugs has been getting increasingly competitive.

And both Ozempic and Wegovy will list for $675 a month.

:: $60 billion

$60 billion worth of AMD’s AI chips will be sold to Meta over the next five years. 

It’s a deal that’ll allow the Facebook owner to purchase as much as 10% of the chip firm. 

It’s AMD’s second mega chip supply deal, having signed a similar pact with OpenAI last year. 

The move was considered a vote of confidence in AMD’s chips and software, significantly boosting its stock price.

headline: Netflix surges as investors cheer decision to exit Warner Bros race
summary: Netflix jumped more than 9% on Friday as investors applauded its decision to exit the race for Warner Bros Discovery, a months-long bidding war with Paramount Skydance ‌for some of Hollywood's most prized assets.  Netflix declined to match Paramount's latest $31 per share bid or raise ‌its offer of $27.75 a share for Warner Bros's studio and streaming assets, stating that the deal was "no longer financially attractive".  The decision was welcomed by ​investors as shares of the streaming giant had shed more than 18% since it announced its deal with Warner Bros on December 5.

Netflix declined to match Paramount's latest $31 per share bid or raise ‌its offer of $27.75 a share for Warner Bros's studio and streaming assets, stating that the deal was "no longer financially attractive".  The decision was welcomed by ​investors as shares of the streaming giant had shed more than 18% since it announced its deal with Warner Bros on December 5.

headline: Paramount Beats Netflix in Months-Long Fight for Warner Bros.
summary: The victory for Paramount Chief Executive Officer David Ellison was hard won, requiring multiple bids over more than five months, visits to Washington, meetings with shareholders and President Donald Trump and the personal backing of his billionaire father Larry Ellison.  Netflix bowed out of its $82.7 billion offer for Warner Bros.’ studio and streaming business on Thursday after the board declared a recent Hail Mary bid from Paramount for the whole company was superior.

headline: How Netflix forced Paramount to cough up more for Warner Bros.
summary: The staggering price, representing one of the biggest media deals in the past decade, came to $31-a-share in cash, or $111 billion including debt, and was high enough for Netflix to walk away rather than increase its offer of $27.75.  Ellison had to add in other sweeteners too, including securing additional backing of his billionaire father, taking on $57.5 billion in debt and agreeing to pay the $2.8 billion breakup fee to Netflix.

content.title: How Netflix forced Paramount to cough up more for Warner Bros.
content.summary: The staggering price, representing one of the biggest media deals in the past decade, came to $31-a-share in cash, or $111 billion including debt, and was high enough for Netflix to walk away rather than increase its offer of $27.75.  Ellison had to add in other sweeteners too, including securing additional backing of his billionaire father, taking on $57.5 billion in debt and agreeing to pay the $2.8 billion breakup fee to Netflix.

headline: Netflix surges as investors cheer exit from Warner Bros race
summary:
STORY: Shares of Netflix jumped as much as eleven-and-a-half percent on Friday, as investors applauded its decision to exit the race for Warner Bros Discovery after a months-long bidding war with Paramount Skydance.

Shares of David Ellison's Paramount, meanwhile, soared more than 20%, as a merger with Warner Bros would allow it to tap into some of Hollywood's most prized assets across film, TV and streaming.

Netflix declined to match Paramount's latest $31 per share bid, or raise its offer of nearly $28 a share, saying the deal was, quote, "no longer financially attractive."

"We were supporting Paramount because we believe in David Ellison..."

Tim Richards, founder and chief executive of privately held cinema operator Vue International, said he supported Paramount's bid of Warner Bros because he viewed it as more likely to prioritize theatrical releases than streaming giant Netflix.

"I'm hoping that Netflix now having really gone in and seen and learned more about how important it is to get a theatrical release, how we are that engine that drives all the ancillary revenue streams, and it's not something to fear, it’s something to embrace, and I'm hoping that some good will come out of that, because we would love to show some of Netflix's amazing movies.”

As for Paramount's streaming unit, a combination with HBO Max and Discovery+ would reshape its position in a streaming era long dominated by Netflix.

Still, one analyst told Reuters that given Warner Bros' debt load, Paramount's acquisition was, quote, "more about Ellison taking over Hollywood and ego than it is about good business sense."

content.title: Netflix surges as investors cheer exit from Warner Bros race
content.summary:
STORY: Shares of Netflix jumped as much as eleven-and-a-half percent on Friday, as investors applauded its decision to exit the race for Warner Bros Discovery after a months-long bidding war with Paramount Skydance.

Shares of David Ellison's Paramount, meanwhile, soared more than 20%, as a merger with Warner Bros would allow it to tap into some of Hollywood's most prized assets across film, TV and streaming.

Netflix declined to match Paramount's latest $31 per share bid, or raise its offer of nearly $28 a share, saying the deal was, quote, "no longer financially attractive."

"We were supporting Paramount because we believe in David Ellison..."

Tim Richards, founder and chief executive of privately held cinema operator Vue International, said he supported Paramount's bid of Warner Bros because he viewed it as more likely to prioritize theatrical releases than streaming giant Netflix.

"I'm hoping that Netflix now having really gone in and seen and learned more about how important it is to get a theatrical release, how we are that engine that drives all the ancillary revenue streams, and it's not something to fear, it’s something to embrace, and I'm hoping that some good will come out of that, because we would love to show some of Netflix's amazing movies.”

As for Paramount's streaming unit, a combination with HBO Max and Discovery+ would reshape its position in a streaming era long dominated by Netflix.

Still, one analyst told Reuters that given Warner Bros' debt load, Paramount's acquisition was, quote, "more about Ellison taking over Hollywood and ego than it is about good business sense."

Ellison had to add in other sweeteners too, including securing additional backing of his billionaire father, taking on $57.5 billion in debt and agreeing to pay the $2.8 billion breakup fee to Netflix.

headline: Paramount must convince regulators its deal with Warner will not hurt customers
summary: After a long, tumultuous fight for Warner Bros. Discovery, the Hollywood giant has finally bested rival bidder Netflix but now faces a new challenge: Winning over regulators.  Paramount’s buyout of Warner Bros. would reshape Hollywood and the wider media landscape in a way that Netflix never threatened to do.  Netflix, which abruptly dropped out of the running this week, wanted only part of Warner.

headline: Netflix Walks Away a Winner After Losing Warner Bros. to Paramount
summary: Paramount is taking on a lot of debt to buy Warner Bros. Discovery, faces a difficult approval process, and will have a tough time absorbing the media giant.

content.title: Netflix Walks Away a Winner After Losing Warner Bros. to Paramount
content.summary: Paramount is taking on a lot of debt to buy Warner Bros. Discovery, faces a difficult approval process, and will have a tough time absorbing the media giant.

headline: Paramount Is Officially Buying Warner Bros. Why the Stock Soared.
summary: Paramount Skydance  investors are set to get a fairy tale ending, with the CBS owner winning the  Warner Bros. Discovery  bidding war.  The companies announced late Friday that Paramount would pay $31 per share in cash for Warner Bros. stock.  It’s a great outcome for Paramount, which only had to raise its hostile tender offer by $1 a share to avoid a prolonged bidding war.

headline: Warner Bros. Discovery signs merger agreement with Paramount Skydance

headline: Netflix says it’s not buying Warner Bros. after all: ‘No longer financially attractive’
summary: In a stunning move, the streaming giant is walking away from the deal it struck in December after Paramount Skydance upped its bid.

headline: Netflix stock price rises along with Paramount while WBD falls. How the merger shakeup is impacting markets
summary: In a surprise move, the streaming giant has decided to walk away from a deal that would have reshaped Hollywood. Some investors appear to be cheering.
